title: Positive integers (as a subset of complex numbers)

blocks.name: cn
blocks.content: Extend class notation to include the class of positive integers.
blocks.origin: const class cn { â„• }

df-nn
blocks.content: Define the set of positive integers. Some authors, especially in analysis books, call these the natural numbers, whereas other authors choose to include 0 in their definition of natural numbers. Note that ` NN ` is a subset of complex numbers ( ~ nnsscn ), in contrast to the more elementary ordinal natural numbers ` _om ` , ~ df-om ). See ~ nnind for the principle of mathematical induction. See ~ df-n0 for the set of nonnegative integers ` NN0 ` . See ~ dfn2 for ` NN ` defined in terms of ` NN0 ` . This is a technical definition that helps us avoid the Axiom of Infinity ~ ax-inf2 in certain proofs. For a more conventional and intuitive definition ("the smallest set of reals containing ` 1 ` as well as the successor of every member") see ~ dfnn3 (or its slight variant ~ dfnn2 ). (Contributed by NM, 10-Jan-1997.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 3-May-2014.)

blocks.name: nnexALT
blocks.content: Alternate proof of ~ nnex , more direct, that makes use of ~ ax-rep . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 3-May-2014.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: peano5nni
blocks.content: Peano's inductive postulate. Theorem I.36 (principle of mathematical induction) of [Apostol] p. 34. (Contributed by NM, 10-Jan-1997.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 17-Nov-2014.)

blocks.name: dfnn2

This definition requires the axiom of infinity to ensure it has the properties we expect. (Contributed by Jeff Hankins, 12-Sep-2013.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 3-May-2014.)

  elintab(s0, nat1, wa(wcel(nat1, cv(s0)), wral(s1, cv(s0), wcel(co(cv(s1), caddc, nat1), cv(s0)))))
  1ex()
